questions.question: What is OSI Model?
questions.answer: OSI (Open Systems Interconnection): 7-layer theoretical model. Layers: Physical (bits), Data Link (frames, MAC), Network (routing, IP), Transport (TCP/UDP), Session (connections), Presentation (encryption, compression), Application (HTTP, SMTP). Data flows down sending, up receiving. Educational framework. Modular design. Guides protocol design. Each layer independent, provides services to above, uses below.

questions.question: What is TCP/IP Model?
questions.answer: TCP/IP: 4-layer practical model. Layers: Application (HTTP, SMTP, DNS), Transport (TCP, UDP), Internet (IP, ICMP), Link (Ethernet, WiFi). Foundation internet communication. Simpler than OSI. Widely implemented. Mapping: OSI App+Presentation+Session = TCP/IP Application; Transport = Transport; Network = Internet; Data Link+Physical = Link. De facto standard replacing OSI.

questions.question: OSI vs TCP/IP?
questions.answer: OSI: 7 layers, theoretical framework, protocol independent, educational. TCP/IP: 4 layers, practical implementation, protocol dependent, widely deployed. OSI explains concepts, TCP/IP actual internet. Mapping combines OSI layers. TCP/IP simpler, easier understand practical. OSI comprehensive, academic. Both useful: OSI learning, TCP/IP real-world. Modern systems typically TCP/IP.

questions.question: What is TCP?
questions.answer: TCP (Transmission Control Protocol): connection-oriented, reliable protocol. Features: 3-way handshake (SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK), ordered delivery (sequence numbers), reliability (retransmits), flow control, error checking (checksum), congestion control, graceful close (4-way). Slower due overhead. Uses: email, web, file transfer, databases. Any accuracy-critical application.

questions.question: What is UDP?
questions.answer: UDP (User Datagram Protocol): connectionless, unreliable protocol. Features: no handshake, unordered, no retransmits, minimal overhead (8-byte header), optional checksum, no flow control, no congestion. Fast, low latency. Uses: streaming, gaming, DNS, VoIP. Speed priority over accuracy. Broadcast/multicast capable.

questions.question: TCP vs UDP?
questions.answer: TCP: connection-oriented, reliable, ordered, slower, overhead. Uses: email, web, files. UDP: connectionless, unreliable, unordered, faster, minimal overhead. Uses: streaming, gaming, DNS. Choose TCP accuracy-critical, UDP speed-critical. TCP guarantees delivery, UDP fire-and-forget. Trade-off reliability vs performance.

questions.question: What is IP Address?
questions.answer: IP address: unique numerical label identifying device network. IPv4: 32-bit (xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx) ~4.3 billion. IPv6: 128-bit (~340 undecillion) future-proof. Identifies network (portion) and host (portion). Subnet mask determines split. Routable globally. Static/dynamic assignment. Essential network identification.

questions.question: What is DNS?
questions.answer: DNS (Domain Name System): translates domain names IP addresses. Process: browser → resolver → root NS → TLD NS → authoritative NS → IP. Records: A (IPv4), AAAA (IPv6), CNAME (alias), MX (mail), NS. Uses port 53, UDP/TCP. Critical internet. Caching speeds lookups. Hierarchical structure.

questions.question: What are Ports?
questions.answer: Port: 16-bit number identifying process/service. Range 0-65535. Well-known (0-1023): SSH(22), HTTP(80), HTTPS(443), SMTP(25), DNS(53). Registered (1024-49151). Dynamic (49152-65535). Enable multiplexing services single IP. Client ephemeral, server well-known. Essential network communication identification.

questions.question: What is Subnet Mask?
questions.answer: Subnet mask: 32-bit number dividing IP network/host portions. Format: 255.255.255.0 or CIDR /24. AND operation IP gives network. Subnetting: divide large network smaller. Example: 192.168.1.0/24 = network 192.168.1.0, hosts 1-254. Enables efficient allocation, management.

questions.question: What is NAT?
questions.answer: NAT (Network Address Translation): translates private IPs public/vice versa. Purpose: multiple devices share public IP, security (hide internal), IPv4 scarcity solution. Types: static (1-to-1), dynamic (pool), PAT (port translation). Example: home network private IPs (192.168.x.x) translate ISP public. Router maintains mapping.

questions.question: What is DHCP?
questions.answer: DHCP (Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol): automatically assigns IPs. Process: DISCOVER → OFFER → REQUEST → ACK. Provides: IP, subnet mask, gateway, DNS, lease time. Port 67/68. Benefits: no manual config, prevents conflicts, easy management. Default lease ~24 hours. Reduces admin overhead. Dynamic allocation.

questions.question: What is HTTP?
questions.answer: HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol): application protocol web. Unsecured, port 80, plain text, no encryption, stateless. Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE. Request-response model. Headers + body. Vulnerable attacks. Replaced HTTPS. Used web browsers, servers.

questions.question: What is HTTPS?
questions.answer: HTTPS: HTTP secured SSL/TLS encryption. Port 443, encrypted data, certificate-verified. Protection: eavesdropping, tampering, man-in-middle. Requires certificate. Slight performance overhead. Modern web default. PCI-DSS requirement. Trusted green lock browser. Essential sensitive data.

questions.question: HTTP vs HTTPS?
questions.answer: HTTP: unsecured, port 80, plain text. HTTPS: secured, port 443, encrypted. HTTPS: protects data, prevents attacks, builds trust, required compliance. HTTP legacy, HTTPS modern standard. Performance difference minimal. All sensitive transactions HTTPS. Modern web HTTPS-only.

questions.question: What is Firewall?
questions.answer: Firewall: security device filtering traffic. Types: hardware (network-level), software (host-level). Functions: packet filtering, stateful inspection, application filtering, NAT. Benefits: blocks unauthorized, prevents malware, logs activity. Limitations: cannot stop insider, encrypted threats, configuration complexity.

questions.question: What is SSL/TLS?
questions.answer: SSL/TLS: cryptographic protocols securing communication. TLS newer version. Features: encryption, authentication (certificate), integrity check, non-repudiation. Handshake: exchange hellos, verify certificate, exchange keys. Used HTTPS, SMTP, IMAP. Protects eavesdropping, tampering. Standard internet security.

questions.question: What is Bandwidth?
questions.answer: Bandwidth: maximum data transfer rate. Measured: bps, Mbps, Gbps. Example 100 Mbps = 100 million bits/second. Limited infrastructure. Like pipeline diameter. Important throughput. Higher bandwidth faster. Shared resource affected congestion.

questions.question: What is Latency?
questions.answer: Latency: time data travels source destination. Measured milliseconds. Lower faster response. Affected: distance, routing, congestion, medium. Critical real-time (gaming, video calls). Like distance traveled. Accumulated hops. Jitter variation problematic.

questions.question: What is Packet Loss?
questions.answer: Packet loss: packets not reaching destination. Causes: congestion, hardware failure, interference, buffers. Measured percentage. Acceptable: wired <0.1%, wireless <2%. Effects: performance degradation, quality issues, lag. Solutions: optimization, error correction, upgrade. TCP retransmits, UDP continues.

questions.question: What is Jitter?
questions.answer: Jitter: variation packet arrival time. Causes: variable latency, routing paths, queuing. Effects: audio distortion, video stuttering, poor VoIP. Measured milliseconds. Acceptable <20ms. Real-time apps sensitive. Caused congestion. Buffer helps mitigate.

questions.question: What is MAC Address?
questions.answer: MAC address: physical address device on LAN. 48-bit hexadecimal (00:1A:2B:3C:4D:5E). Format: manufacturer ID (3 bytes) + device ID (3 bytes). Layer 2 (data link). Local network scope. ARP converts IP MAC. Unique LAN. Broadcast LAN.

questions.question: What is ARP?
questions.answer: ARP (Address Resolution Protocol): maps IP addresses MAC addresses. Process: broadcast ARP request IP, device with IP responds MAC, cache updated. Used first-time communication LAN. Cache speeds future. ARP spoofing attack (fake mapping). Security concern. Fundamental LAN communication.

questions.question: What is ICMP?
questions.answer: ICMP (Internet Control Message Protocol): network diagnostics, error reporting. Uses: echo (ping), traceroute, error messages (unreachable, timeout). ICMP echo reply = ping response. Important troubleshooting. Often blocked firewalls. No direct data. Carries no user data.

questions.question: What is Ping?
questions.answer: Ping: utility testing connectivity ICMP echo. Sends echo request, measures response. Shows: connectivity, latency, packet loss. Output: response time (ms), TTL. Diagnostic tool. Commonly blocked firewalls. Simple connectivity check. Quick network validation.

questions.question: What is Traceroute?
questions.answer: Traceroute: tool showing packet route. ICMP increasing TTL. Shows: hops, latency per hop, delays. Helps: identify problems, locate failures. Variants: tracert (Windows), traceroute (Linux). Diagnostic network issues. Reveals path taken routing.

questions.question: What is VPN?
questions.answer: VPN (Virtual Private Network): encrypted tunnel public network. Benefits: privacy, security, bypass restrictions, remote access. Protocols: IPsec, OpenVPN, L2TP, PPTP. Secure connection. Appears different location. Protects traffic encryption. Used corporate, privacy-conscious users.

questions.question: What is Proxy?
questions.answer: Proxy: intermediary client server. Types: forward (client's proxy), reverse (server's proxy), transparent. Benefits: anonymity, caching, access control, filtering. Acts substitute. Modifies requests/responses. Web proxies filter content. Load balancing uses.

questions.question: What is CDN?
questions.answer: CDN (Content Delivery Network): distributed network serving content nearest location. Benefits: faster delivery, reduced latency, bandwidth savings, redundancy. Works: cache globally, serve locally. Used static, videos, files. Improves user experience. Geographically distributed.

questions.question: What is Load Balancing?
questions.answer: Load balancing: distributing traffic across servers. Algorithms: round robin, least connections, IP hash, weighted. Benefits: availability, performance, scalability, failover. Methods: hardware, software, DNS. Essential scaling. Prevents single point failure.

questions.question: What is BGP?
questions.answer: BGP (Border Gateway Protocol): routing protocol between autonomous systems (ISPs). Exterior gateway. Dynamically selects routes. Path vector algorithm. Critical internet routing. Scales globally. Complex configuration. Enables internet interconnection. Announcements/withdrawals.

questions.question: What is OSPF?
questions.answer: OSPF (Open Shortest Path First): interior gateway protocol within autonomous systems. Link-state algorithm. Convergence faster RIP. Supports hierarchical. Metric: cost (bandwidth-based). Scales well. Industry standard. Faster RIP. More complex.

questions.question: What is RIP?
questions.answer: RIP (Routing Information Protocol): interior gateway protocol. Older, simpler. Metric: hop count (max 15). Broadcast routing periodically. Convergence slow. Limited scalability. Largely replaced. Less efficient. Educational mainly.

questions.question: What is Spanning Tree Protocol?
questions.answer: STP: prevents loops switched networks. Selects bridges, disables redundant links. Port states: listening, learning, forwarding, blocking. Convergence 50 seconds. RSTP (rapid) faster (6 seconds). Important switch redundancy. Prevents broadcast storms. Loop detection.

questions.question: What is VLAN?
questions.answer: VLAN (Virtual LAN): logically grouping devices different physical networks. Segmentation: department, function, security. Benefits: segmentation, security, broadcast containment, management. Tagged frames carry VLAN ID. Reduces broadcast domain. Logical organization.

questions.question: What is Multicast?
questions.answer: Multicast: one-to-many communication. IP range 224.0.0.0-239.255.255.255. Groups: well-known, transient. Benefits: efficient bandwidth, scalable, selective delivery. Uses: video streaming, IPTV, routing protocols. More efficient broadcast.

questions.question: What is Anycast?
questions.answer: Anycast: one-to-nearest communication. Multiple devices share address. Packets route nearest. Uses: DNS (root servers), CDN, load distribution. Improves performance. Transparent client. Efficient routing.

questions.question: What is Broadcast?
questions.answer: Broadcast: one-to-all communication. Destination 255.255.255.255 (IPv4). Local network scope. Packets flood LAN. Inefficient: all receive. Limited range. Used ARP, DHCP, discovery. Vs multicast: targeted.

questions.question: What is TTL?
questions.answer: TTL (Time To Live): field IP header. Decremented hop. Prevents infinite loops. Original value: usually 64/128. Reaches 0: discarded. Used traceroute increases. Cross-network communication. Essential IP.

questions.question: What is Checksum?
questions.answer: Checksum: error detection mechanism. Calculated header/data. Receiver recalculates, compares. Detects corruption. Not corrects. Simple detection. IP header has checksum. TCP/UDP optional (IPv4) required (IPv6). Data integrity.

questions.question: What is CRC?
questions.answer: CRC (Cyclic Redundancy Check): polynomial division error detection. More robust checksum. Detects burst errors. Used Ethernet, storage. Trade-off computation accuracy. Stronger checksum. Doesn't correct.

questions.question: What is Handshake?
questions.answer: Handshake: initial exchange establishing connection. TCP 3-way: SYN, SYN-ACK, ACK. SSL/TLS similar. Establishes parameters. Authenticates parties. Negotiates capabilities. Overhead: RTT latency. Essential reliable.

questions.question: What is Congestion Control?
questions.answer: Congestion control: TCP managing network overload. Algorithms: slow start, congestion avoidance, fast retransmit, recovery. Adjusts window size. Reduces sending rate. Prevents collapse. Dynamic adjustment. Improves fairness.

questions.question: What is Flow Control?
questions.answer: Flow control: preventing sender overwhelming receiver. TCP advertises window size. Sender respects. Receiver buffers. Prevents loss. Adjustable. Different congestion (network vs receiver). Prevents overrun.

questions.question: What is Sliding Window?
questions.answer: Sliding window: flow control mechanism. Sender transmits up window size before ACK. Window slides each ACK. Allows pipelined. Improves efficiency. TCP uses. Balances throughput buffering.

questions.question: What is Retransmission?
questions.answer: Retransmission: resending lost packets. Timeout detects loss. Sequence number identifies. TCP retransmits. Exponential backoff increases timeout. Duplicate detection ignores. Ensures reliability. Adds latency. Accuracy-latency trade.

questions.question: What is 3-Way Handshake?
questions.answer: 3-way handshake: TCP connection establishment. 1) Client SYN (seq=x); 2) Server SYN-ACK (seq=y, ack=x+1); 3) Client ACK (seq=x+1, ack=y+1). Establishes sequence numbers. Synchronizes. Acknowledges. Enables ordered delivery.

questions.question: What is 4-Way Termination?
questions.answer: 4-way termination: TCP closing. 1) Client FIN; 2) Server ACK; 3) Server FIN; 4) Client ACK. TIME_WAIT ensures delayed packets. Allows reuse after. Graceful close. Orderly termination.

questions.question: What is MSS?
questions.answer: MSS (Maximum Segment Size): largest data TCP sends. Negotiated handshake. Calculated MTU - headers. Default 536 bytes (minimum), typically 1460 (Ethernet). Avoids fragmentation. Improves efficiency. Per-connection.

questions.question: What is MTU?
questions.answer: MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit): largest frame network sends. Default 1500 bytes (Ethernet). Includes header. Large: fragmentation. Small: overhead. Path discovery finds minimum. Affects performance. Can adjust typically standard.
